VOL. XXXI, NO. 9
JAY CROSS COUNTRY TEAM
MEETS MARYLAND
TOMORROW
Eight Men to Journey to College
Park; Schedule of Three
Meets Booked

Eight and possibly nine crosscountry men will leave Hopkins tomorrow for College Park, where
they will engage the Black and Gold

Do
20

in a six and a quarter mile run,
starting and
ending at Byrd
Stadium.
Course Not Difficult

K"

Captain Gwinn, Schiebel, Schiedt,
Kirkpatrick,
Day, Kelly, Langor,
Wheeler, and possibly Scow, are
the men who will make the trip.
Fsive of these, Gwinn, Schiebel,
Schiedt, Day,
and Kelly, went down
to College Park last Saturday, and
ran the full course, finding it not
as difficult a one as that on which
the team practices.
Nothing definite can be predicted
concerning
tile meet tomorrow, except that whichever way goes, the
it
score is expected to be close. The
race will start at two-thirty, and
Will be timed
so that it will end between the halves of the football
game.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 29, 1926

FROSH BASEBALL
PRACTICE BEGUN
Freshman Class baseball
practice was begun last Tuesday behind the engineering
buildings. The yearlings were
under the direction and coaching of Thomas McNeal, '27,
ex-varsity mound artist.
Batting practice and fielding tryouts were held while
McNeal looked over the
would-be pitchers. The first
of the interclass games will be
held in the near future.

MUSICAL CLUBS TO MAKE
NORFOLK TRIP—
PASSANO

February 19

"The Johns Hopkins Musical
Club shall make a trip to Norfolk
this season," said Edward M. Passano, president, recently. After this
startling piece of news he went on
to say that the tentative date for the
concert and dance, which will be
given in the ballroom of the Hotel
Monticello, Norfolk, has been set
for February 19. This will necessitate the club's starting Friday evening the 18th and returning in time
for classes Monday morning.
It has been found that it would
be very unsatisfactory to attempt a
longer trip through the South since
there is no financial support in any
of the neighboring cities. Even in
Norfolk, no single organization can
be obtained as guarantor of expenses.
New Methods

The Club has adopted rather different methods from the past under
the direction of its new officers,
Passano ,and McElfresh. They
have decided to furnish transportation and sleeping facilities for the
Varsity members of the Club and
to take care of all expenses in connection with the giving of their concerts and dances. They have planned, however, to have the Club
members pay for their own 'meals
while traveling in preference to
asking for a lump sum from each
individual.
President Passano states that he
has practically made ,up his mind
to make the round-trip to Norfolk
on the boats of the Chesapeake
Steamship Co.
Substitutes Invited

Although the Club only guarantees to pay for the Varsity members as selected for that date, it is
highly desirous of having as many
substitutes as possible make the
trip with them.
To further quote President Passano, he said, "I not only expect
the substitutes to go with us, but
after talking to many formed Musical Club members and undergraduates n6t connected with the Club,
I expect a number, at least equal
to the Varsity, to help us make it
a real Hopkins party."

Instructor, Hurt In
Explosion, Doing Well
Mr. Donald Bonney, an instructor in Gas Engineering, who was injured a short time ago, when a gas
tank exploded in back of the Mechanical Engineering Building, is
convalescing in the Marburg Ward
of the Johns Hopkins University.
Bonney will probably return to the
dormitory in another week or so.
As far as can be determined no
serious complications have set in.

Syracuse List Same

The Syracuse list will also be the
same as last week, except for Borysinger, star Orange quarterback,
who resigned from the squad following a disagreement with a referee in the Army game. Cooke, who
will replace him, is reputed to be
equally as good.
The Syracuse )star is Hansonk
end and captain. He is All-American and has been playing a stellar
game at the wing position this year.
High Age Average

NO TEA DANCE
HERE TOMORROW
The Cotillon Club will not
hold a dance this Saturday
afternoon in the C. E. Hall.
This decision was reached in
view of the football team's
trip to Syracuse to encounter
the strong Orange eleven tomorrow.
It was suggested that the
Club hold the usual tea dance
anyway for those undergraduates that might attend the
Navy-Michigan game at the
Stadium, but this motion was
defeated. Consequently, there
will be no dance .tomorrow
afternoon.

The Orange team has the striking age average of twenty-two years
and no man is under twenty-one.
They weigh 172 pounds,' out-pointing the Jays by three pounds per
man. The average advantage is distributed throughout both the line
and the backfield.
This is the second time that the
Jays have played the Yellow-jackets. The first game opened the season of 1920 and the Blue went
down in defeat 52-0.
The Hopkins team is expected to
be on the defensive a large part of
tomorrow's game, so that Lyons's
kicking and safety work, and Boynton's backing up of the line should
be features of the contest.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1926

SELETZKY PRESIDENT OF
COSMOPOLITAN CLUB

THE NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
Meetings

Will Be Held in
Meeting House

Friends

A. C. Seletzky of Russia Was
elected president of the Cosmopolitan Club at a meeting held last Saturday evening. Fife Colimore of
Italy was made vice-president. The
other officers chosen were C. K. Wu
of China, treasurer, and Oscar Martinez of Mexico, secretary.
The meeting was surprisingly
well attended. In addition to the
election of officers there was an enjoyable program, the chief feature
of which was a piano solo by Mr.
Paul Bilotti.
It was announced that the next
meeting of the club will be in the
form of an international student
conference to be held from Friday
to Sunday of next week.
All foreign students attending
universities and colleges in Maryland, Delaware and the District of
Columbia have been invited, and it
is expected that many delegates will
attend.
For purposes of study and discussion, the conference will be divided into six commissions, which
will deal with the major aspects of
the international question. These
commissions are: political factors,
economic factors, social factors, inherent factors, religious factors, and
immigration.
All meetings and entertainments
of the conference will be held at
the Homewood Friends' Meeting
House on North Charles Street.

DORM DOINGS
Last Saturday afternoon approximately two hundred and fifty guests
of the johns Hopkins University's
fiftieth anniversary celebration were
present at the unveiling of the
bronze memorial tablet in the entrance of the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory. This tablet bears the
names of those Hopkins men who
gave their lives in the World 'War.
It, like the buildings on the Homewood campus, is characterized by
simplicity. Already has this tablet been an inspiration to a few residents.
Mr. Edmund S. Lynch, of the
class of 1907 and now vice-president of the Pathe Weekly Corporation, was one of the many notables
present at the unveiling exercises
Saturday. The name of his brother, C. Vernon Lynch, '14, appears
on the tablet. Mr. Lynch secured
experienced Pathe photographers to
make a pictorial record of the prominent feature's during the anniversary celebrations. The pictures of
the more important exercises will
probably be shown in Baltimore
theatres during the next several
weeks. These pictures will be donated . to the University by Mr.
Lynch as permanent records of the
celebration.

CUM LAUDE
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
In view of the fact that this is
probably the last issue of the NEWSLETTER to appear before the departure of our esteemed friend, Dr.
Charles K. Edmunds, we take this
opportunity of expressing our chagrin.
Dr. Edmunds has been Provost
of the University for two and a
half years. During that time he has
organized the Alumni, greatly improved the financial status of the
University, planned and executed
the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration, reorganized the Administrative Department of the University
—in short, in a thousand ways made
himself invaluable. No other member of the University has devoted
so much time and loyalty to his
work. Dr. Edmunds's hours have
often been from 8:00 A. M. to
7:00 P. M., plus night work.
It is with the greatest regret that
we see him go—the more so because without him the Student Activities Building may .not be realized.
Best wishes for your success in
your new field, Dr. Edmunds. May
-you always prosper!
Regretfully,
RUSTICUS.
MORE DISGUSTS
To the Editor Of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
It gave • me.much gratification to
note the letter of "Disgusted" in a
recent issue of your paper. I, also,
am taking French I, and although
I cannot be quite as harsh as your
first correspondent, I find a very
serious lack in the course. Of
course, it is not the fault of the
French department that one of the
sections must be held in a room too
small for it; but in the study of a
language, one does not have the
spontaneous interest aroused by
other more abstract subjects. Therefore, the subject-matter should be
doubly vital. Anyone who has read
modern English prose can hardly
find "Columbia" enthralling. It is
undeniably puerile. And even if a
seemingly sterile tennis game be
substituted for the yet sometimes
present blue pencils of "Disgusted's" letter, a college man cannot
he expected actually to take interest in such grammar lessons. Perhaps the vocabularies contained

SENIORS ONLY
It strikes us, as we think back, that traditions have been mentioned in this column before, therefore we are put to it to begin
in this way in order to be just a little different in dragging tradition before the undergraduate gaze again.
The freshman cap has been relegated to the past, along with
a few other ancient customs that gave each class more freedom
as it advanced. Only one tradition of importance has been left
to the seniors at this time of the year. Of course, they are supposed to sing songs and graduate in June, with other old customs
thrown in, but now they walk the campus like any other human
undergraduate would. There is but one exception. Seniors
are permitted to walk through the Memorial Room in Gilman
Hall.
At present all .the glory of this custom that is left to a senior
is the self-satisfaction in knowing that he alone can walk through
the Memorial Room with a clear conscience. Even this, however,
is waning, for when he tries to make use of his privilege he meets
on his way members of all classes using the same privilege, evidently with an equally clear conscience.
The janitors are instructed to permit only seniors among
the undergraduates to stroll through the Memorial Room, but the
only offenders they can readily recognize are freshmen. The
other half of the undergraduate body swaggers along unmolested,
even appearing insulted if reminded of their wrong-doing.
They fail to consider that they, too, will probably some day
he seniors themselves, and, unless they stop their usurping of
seniors' rights, will also be usurped upon. If this realization
does not take effect, appealing to that selfishness in everyone, we
fear more drastic means of enforcing the waning tradition will
be called upon in the future.
R.

UNCONSCIOUS HYPOCRITES
Students come to the University daily, go into the building
to attend classes, and return home, never wandering elsewhere
on the campus. When asked, they will tell you that Johns Hopkins has one of the most beautiful surroundings of any univer•
sity in the country. They read that somewhere, or some one
told them so.
If such a student would wander back of the Botanical Garden into the woods, along one of the twisting, leafy paths, he
would tell you that Hopkins has a beautiful campus. He will
have read it in the color of the autumn-tinted leaves, or his most
unapproachable heart will have told him so.
R.

YES and NO

SPEAKING
OF

In Memoriam
It seems that it makes little if any difference how badly a
given policy falls by the way in accomplishing a desired end;
it will at any rate find ardent supporters. To wit—this Interfraternity Board agreement for the open week is no exception.
Upon opening our post office box a morning or so ago we
found frothing objection to our table in last week's Column in the
form of anonymous letters from disturbed Greeks.
The first was to the effect that we had intentions on the
mouldable structure of the freshman mind; that we were spouting bombast; that it gave said Freshmen an alarming temerity
complex and further that it created a great. deal of work for
those burning souls, the salesmen of "Friendship never dies."
Ah, even that we were combating the beautiful ideal of the above
Board by writing such drivel.
The other bore the general connotation of you are a smart
guy, ain't you? To the latter we have no reply—since he answers
his own question. Occasionally we appreciate his point of you.
To the former, however, we feel.differently disposed. For
we, too, are curious in knowing what "beautiful ideal" the Interfraternity Board had hoped to achieve by the open week. The
accomplished result is—well, just what is it?'Sundry chapter
treasuries are sadly depleted, and the freshmen are going the
same way as they were before—a quoi bon the open week?
We modify our opinion of our own accord in adding that
the delerious stage will not lead a freshman astray since they
have a week of headaches in which to think it over. We opine
now that the open week was bad simply because it was useless.

Contribution to the realm of the drama by the up-to-theminute Sophomore delegation:
George (over telephone): Do you want to go along with me
to see "Young Woodley" this afternoon? I am taking A. Given
Frosh and thought perhaps you would like to take in the opportunity.
Nathan (in answer): Woodley ? Yeh—alright, but wait,
I've really got some studying to do, haven't cracked a book since
rushing season began. So listen, you take A. G. Frosh and entertain him for a couple of hours, anywhere, hear? Then I'll
meet you with my car at Charles and Fayette at 5 o'clock and
I'll go up and spend a half hour or so with this boy Woodley
with you.

We accepted a challenge from an esteemed member of the
faculty in the manner of how much an undergraduate really
thinks. The discussion was centered upon the following opinion
from Samuel Butler's -Way of All Flesh." Some people say
that their school days were the happiest of their lives. .They may
be right, but I always look with suspicion upon people whom I
hear saying this.

The professor was most self-convinced that the average college student could not think long or straight enough to enunciate
whether he was happy or not. Let it suffice that we thought differently. But good students note in passing that we, in a moment
of rashness, stated that we could see published any amount of
sound analysis on the question of Happiness as appreciated in

an exhibition of uphill fighting unequaled in the East• this season,
completely outplaying their rivals in
every branch of the game.

The Navy eleven, due solely to
a break, defeated Colgate last Saturday when Lloyd, Navy end,

won a well-earned victory over one
of the strongest teams that has ever
represented the Naval Academy.

VOL. XXXI, NO. 9
JAY CROSS COUNTRY TEAM
MEETS MARYLAND
TOMORROW
Eight Men to Journey to College
Park; Schedule of Three
Meets Booked

Eight and possibly nine crosscountry men will leave Hopkins tomorrow for College Park, where
they will engage the Black and Gold

Do
20

in a six and a quarter mile run,
starting and
ending at Byrd
Stadium.
Course Not Difficult

K"

Captain Gwinn, Schiebel, Schiedt,
Kirkpatrick,
Day, Kelly, Langor,
Wheeler, and possibly Scow, are
the men who will make the trip.
Fsive of these, Gwinn, Schiebel,
Schiedt, Day,
and Kelly, went down
to College Park last Saturday, and
ran the full course, finding it not
as difficult a one as that on which
the team practices.
Nothing definite can be predicted
concerning
tile meet tomorrow, except that whichever way goes, the
it
score is expected to be close. The
race will start at two-thirty, and
Will be timed
so that it will end between the halves of the football
game.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., OCTOBER 29, 1926

FROSH BASEBALL
PRACTICE BEGUN
Freshman Class baseball
practice was begun last Tuesday behind the engineering
buildings. The yearlings were
under the direction and coaching of Thomas McNeal, '27,
ex-varsity mound artist.
Batting practice and fielding tryouts were held while
McNeal looked over the
would-be pitchers. The first
of the interclass games will be
held in the near future.

MUSICAL CLUBS TO MAKE
NORFOLK TRIP—
PASSANO

February 19

"The Johns Hopkins Musical
Club shall make a trip to Norfolk
this season," said Edward M. Passano, president, recently. After this
startling piece of news he went on
to say that the tentative date for the
concert and dance, which will be
given in the ballroom of the Hotel
Monticello, Norfolk, has been set
for February 19. This will necessitate the club's starting Friday evening the 18th and returning in time
for classes Monday morning.
It has been found that it would
be very unsatisfactory to attempt a
longer trip through the South since
there is no financial support in any
of the neighboring cities. Even in
Norfolk, no single organization can
be obtained as guarantor of expenses.
New Methods

The Club has adopted rather different methods from the past under
the direction of its new officers,
Passano ,and McElfresh. They
have decided to furnish transportation and sleeping facilities for the
Varsity members of the Club and
to take care of all expenses in connection with the giving of their concerts and dances. They have planned, however, to have the Club
members pay for their own 'meals
while traveling in preference to
asking for a lump sum from each
individual.
President Passano states that he
has practically made ,up his mind
to make the round-trip to Norfolk
on the boats of the Chesapeake
Steamship Co.
Substitutes Invited

Although the Club only guarantees to pay for the Varsity members as selected for that date, it is
highly desirous of having as many
substitutes as possible make the
trip with them.
To further quote President Passano, he said, "I not only expect
the substitutes to go with us, but
after talking to many formed Musical Club members and undergraduates n6t connected with the Club,
I expect a number, at least equal
to the Varsity, to help us make it
a real Hopkins party."

Instructor, Hurt In
Explosion, Doing Well
Mr. Donald Bonney, an instructor in Gas Engineering, who was injured a short time ago, when a gas
tank exploded in back of the Mechanical Engineering Building, is
convalescing in the Marburg Ward
of the Johns Hopkins University.
Bonney will probably return to the
dormitory in another week or so.
As far as can be determined no
serious complications have set in.

Syracuse List Same

The Syracuse list will also be the
same as last week, except for Borysinger, star Orange quarterback,
who resigned from the squad following a disagreement with a referee in the Army game. Cooke, who
will replace him, is reputed to be
equally as good.
The Syracuse )star is Hansonk
end and captain. He is All-American and has been playing a stellar
game at the wing position this year.
High Age Average

NO TEA DANCE
HERE TOMORROW
The Cotillon Club will not
hold a dance this Saturday
afternoon in the C. E. Hall.
This decision was reached in
view of the football team's
trip to Syracuse to encounter
the strong Orange eleven tomorrow.
It was suggested that the
Club hold the usual tea dance
anyway for those undergraduates that might attend the
Navy-Michigan game at the
Stadium, but this motion was
defeated. Consequently, there
will be no dance .tomorrow
afternoon.

The Orange team has the striking age average of twenty-two years
and no man is under twenty-one.
They weigh 172 pounds,' out-pointing the Jays by three pounds per
man. The average advantage is distributed throughout both the line
and the backfield.
This is the second time that the
Jays have played the Yellow-jackets. The first game opened the season of 1920 and the Blue went
down in defeat 52-0.
The Hopkins team is expected to
be on the defensive a large part of
tomorrow's game, so that Lyons's
kicking and safety work, and Boynton's backing up of the line should
be features of the contest.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, OCTOBER 29, 1926

SELETZKY PRESIDENT OF
COSMOPOLITAN CLUB

THE NEWS-LETTER

MAILBAG
Meetings

Will Be Held in
Meeting House

Friends

A. C. Seletzky of Russia Was
elected president of the Cosmopolitan Club at a meeting held last Saturday evening. Fife Colimore of
Italy was made vice-president. The
other officers chosen were C. K. Wu
of China, treasurer, and Oscar Martinez of Mexico, secretary.
The meeting was surprisingly
well attended. In addition to the
election of officers there was an enjoyable program, the chief feature
of which was a piano solo by Mr.
Paul Bilotti.
It was announced that the next
meeting of the club will be in the
form of an international student
conference to be held from Friday
to Sunday of next week.
All foreign students attending
universities and colleges in Maryland, Delaware and the District of
Columbia have been invited, and it
is expected that many delegates will
attend.
For purposes of study and discussion, the conference will be divided into six commissions, which
will deal with the major aspects of
the international question. These
commissions are: political factors,
economic factors, social factors, inherent factors, religious factors, and
immigration.
All meetings and entertainments
of the conference will be held at
the Homewood Friends' Meeting
House on North Charles Street.

DORM DOINGS
Last Saturday afternoon approximately two hundred and fifty guests
of the johns Hopkins University's
fiftieth anniversary celebration were
present at the unveiling of the
bronze memorial tablet in the entrance of the Alumni Memorial
Dormitory. This tablet bears the
names of those Hopkins men who
gave their lives in the World 'War.
It, like the buildings on the Homewood campus, is characterized by
simplicity. Already has this tablet been an inspiration to a few residents.
Mr. Edmund S. Lynch, of the
class of 1907 and now vice-president of the Pathe Weekly Corporation, was one of the many notables
present at the unveiling exercises
Saturday. The name of his brother, C. Vernon Lynch, '14, appears
on the tablet. Mr. Lynch secured
experienced Pathe photographers to
make a pictorial record of the prominent feature's during the anniversary celebrations. The pictures of
the more important exercises will
probably be shown in Baltimore
theatres during the next several
weeks. These pictures will be donated . to the University by Mr.
Lynch as permanent records of the
celebration.

CUM LAUDE
To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
In view of the fact that this is
probably the last issue of the NEWSLETTER to appear before the departure of our esteemed friend, Dr.
Charles K. Edmunds, we take this
opportunity of expressing our chagrin.
Dr. Edmunds has been Provost
of the University for two and a
half years. During that time he has
organized the Alumni, greatly improved the financial status of the
University, planned and executed
the Fiftieth Anniversary Celebration, reorganized the Administrative Department of the University
—in short, in a thousand ways made
himself invaluable. No other member of the University has devoted
so much time and loyalty to his
work. Dr. Edmunds's hours have
often been from 8:00 A. M. to
7:00 P. M., plus night work.
It is with the greatest regret that
we see him go—the more so because without him the Student Activities Building may .not be realized.
Best wishes for your success in
your new field, Dr. Edmunds. May
-you always prosper!
Regretfully,
RUSTICUS.
MORE DISGUSTS
To the Editor Of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:
It gave • me.much gratification to
note the letter of "Disgusted" in a
recent issue of your paper. I, also,
am taking French I, and although
I cannot be quite as harsh as your
first correspondent, I find a very
serious lack in the course. Of
course, it is not the fault of the
French department that one of the
sections must be held in a room too
small for it; but in the study of a
language, one does not have the
spontaneous interest aroused by
other more abstract subjects. Therefore, the subject-matter should be
doubly vital. Anyone who has read
modern English prose can hardly
find "Columbia" enthralling. It is
undeniably puerile. And even if a
seemingly sterile tennis game be
substituted for the yet sometimes
present blue pencils of "Disgusted's" letter, a college man cannot
he expected actually to take interest in such grammar lessons. Perhaps the vocabularies contained

SENIORS ONLY
It strikes us, as we think back, that traditions have been mentioned in this column before, therefore we are put to it to begin
in this way in order to be just a little different in dragging tradition before the undergraduate gaze again.
The freshman cap has been relegated to the past, along with
a few other ancient customs that gave each class more freedom
as it advanced. Only one tradition of importance has been left
to the seniors at this time of the year. Of course, they are supposed to sing songs and graduate in June, with other old customs
thrown in, but now they walk the campus like any other human
undergraduate would. There is but one exception. Seniors
are permitted to walk through the Memorial Room in Gilman
Hall.
At present all .the glory of this custom that is left to a senior
is the self-satisfaction in knowing that he alone can walk through
the Memorial Room with a clear conscience. Even this, however,
is waning, for when he tries to make use of his privilege he meets
on his way members of all classes using the same privilege, evidently with an equally clear conscience.
The janitors are instructed to permit only seniors among
the undergraduates to stroll through the Memorial Room, but the
only offenders they can readily recognize are freshmen. The
other half of the undergraduate body swaggers along unmolested,
even appearing insulted if reminded of their wrong-doing.
They fail to consider that they, too, will probably some day
he seniors themselves, and, unless they stop their usurping of
seniors' rights, will also be usurped upon. If this realization
does not take effect, appealing to that selfishness in everyone, we
fear more drastic means of enforcing the waning tradition will
be called upon in the future.
R.

UNCONSCIOUS HYPOCRITES
Students come to the University daily, go into the building
to attend classes, and return home, never wandering elsewhere
on the campus. When asked, they will tell you that Johns Hopkins has one of the most beautiful surroundings of any univer•
sity in the country. They read that somewhere, or some one
told them so.
If such a student would wander back of the Botanical Garden into the woods, along one of the twisting, leafy paths, he
would tell you that Hopkins has a beautiful campus. He will
have read it in the color of the autumn-tinted leaves, or his most
unapproachable heart will have told him so.
R.

SPEAKING
OF

In Memoriam
It seems that it makes little if any difference how badly a
given policy falls by the way in accomplishing a desired end;
it will at any rate find ardent supporters. To wit—this Interfraternity Board agreement for the open week is no exception.
Upon opening our post office box a morning or so ago we
found frothing objection to our table in last week's Column in the
form of anonymous letters from disturbed Greeks.
The first was to the effect that we had intentions on the
mouldable structure of the freshman mind; that we were spouting bombast; that it gave said Freshmen an alarming temerity
complex and further that it created a great. deal of work for
those burning souls, the salesmen of "Friendship never dies."
Ah, even that we were combating the beautiful ideal of the above
Board by writing such drivel.
The other bore the general connotation of you are a smart
guy, ain't you? To the latter we have no reply—since he answers
his own question. Occasionally we appreciate his point of you.
To the former, however, we feel.differently disposed. For
we, too, are curious in knowing what "beautiful ideal" the Interfraternity Board had hoped to achieve by the open week. The
accomplished result is—well, just what is it?'Sundry chapter
treasuries are sadly depleted, and the freshmen are going the
same way as they were before—a quoi bon the open week?
We modify our opinion of our own accord in adding that
the delerious stage will not lead a freshman astray since they
have a week of headaches in which to think it over. We opine
now that the open week was bad simply because it was useless.

Contribution to the realm of the drama by the up-to-theminute Sophomore delegation:
George (over telephone): Do you want to go along with me
to see "Young Woodley" this afternoon? I am taking A. Given
Frosh and thought perhaps you would like to take in the opportunity.
Nathan (in answer): Woodley ? Yeh—alright, but wait,
I've really got some studying to do, haven't cracked a book since
rushing season began. So listen, you take A. G. Frosh and entertain him for a couple of hours, anywhere, hear? Then I'll
meet you with my car at Charles and Fayette at 5 o'clock and
I'll go up and spend a half hour or so with this boy Woodley
with you.

We accepted a challenge from an esteemed member of the
faculty in the manner of how much an undergraduate really
thinks. The discussion was centered upon the following opinion
from Samuel Butler's -Way of All Flesh." Some people say
that their school days were the happiest of their lives. .They may
be right, but I always look with suspicion upon people whom I
hear saying this.

The professor was most self-convinced that the average college student could not think long or straight enough to enunciate
whether he was happy or not. Let it suffice that we thought differently. But good students note in passing that we, in a moment
of rashness, stated that we could see published any amount of
sound analysis on the question of Happiness as appreciated in
College. Don't desert us, nor let the pedagogue persist in his illusion—submit an argument!

SPORTS
Although defeated by Holy Cross,
conquerors of Harvard, Western
Maryland gave the Purple a great
battle last Saturday in a game that
was not decided until the final whistle, the final score being 21 to 14.
The Green Terrors trailing Holy
Cross 21 to 0 at half time, came
back in the second half and gave
an exhibition of uphill fighting unequaled in the East• this season,
completely outplaying their rivals in
every branch of the game.

The Navy eleven, due solely to
a break, defeated Colgate last Saturday when Lloyd, Navy end,
picked up a fumble in the last minute of play with the score 7-6
against the Middies and ran 99
yards for a touchdown thus turning a Navy defeat into victory.
The New York team decidedly
outplayed the Midshipmen throughout the entire game and but for
this unfortunate fumble would have
won a well-earned victory over one
of the strongest teams that has ever
represented the Naval Academy.

Shaughnessy, big Colgate fullback, gave an excellent performance
up until the time when his fumble
paved the way for the Navy victorY•
Alan Shapley, Navy's backfield
star, who has been out of the gain°
for several weeks, due to injuries,
will be able to start against Michigan and will bolster the Navy attack considerably.

Michigan was victorious over Illinois last week, in a stubbornlY
but remarkably cleanly played gatile,
the final score being 13 to 0.
Michigan, by winning SaturdaY
thus eliminated Illinois from the
Western Conference champions14.

Benny Friedman, they were unable
